page.title: 06History of Middleton
page.content: When Neolithic farmers built their great ceremonial circle of Arbor Low high up on Middleton Moor and raised barrows for their dead on the surrounding hill tops, the region now occupied by the civil parish of Middleton an Smerrill must have been a populous centre of regional culture. Now the area has a population of only about 150. Of the medieval village of Smerrill only the great grange farm survives. During the period of the Civil War, Sir Christopher Fullwood, whose castle was at Middleton, became the chief royalist supporter in the area. He was subsequently killed while escaping from a parliamentary search party in Bradford Dale. The chief industry in the 18th and 19th centuries was lace making. There was also a bobbin mill, and work in agriculture and lead mines
